September 17, 1968
PROGRAM PROPOSALS FOR EDUCATIONAL RADIO STATIONS
Experiments with Sound
On the CBS Television program "On the Road" broadcast
September 3, 1968, the narrator, Charles Kuralt con¬
cluded by saying, "You don»t have to look — you can
close your eyes and listen to America*"
Educational radio has been broadcasting programs for
almost fifty years* Never in that time has there been
money available to permit a series of uninhibited,
creative experiments with the aural medium.
The claim has been made time and again that there
are creative production people In educational radio
but they can*t "do anything" because of the insuf¬
ficient financial base.
The September 9, 1968 Broadcasting magazine reports
that Tony Schwartz, president of New Sounds, Inc.,
New York will conduct a new study for distribution
to major advertisers and agencies.
The president of the sponsoring firm, H. D. Neuwirth
of Metro Radio Sales, explains, "Our goal is not to
show how to use sound effects but, rather how sound
affects people. We feel that advertisers should know
how sound affects people. We want to show what people
hear and what they react to. We want to show what
motivates them to buy, and we feel that the mea
spending money in our medium want to know these ans¬
wers too."
Radio is a medium of imagination. If the creative
talent exists to bring imagery of an audience into
action, financial support should be provided for
experimentation•
Raymond Swing suggested, "If the eye gets into the
act, the mind's contribution id diluted."
The opportunity for aural experimentation in edu¬
cational broadcasting should be encouraged.
